articles.headline: Benedict Meets With the Victims of Sexual Abuse
articles.snippet: The meeting made clear that a message concerning priestly abuse was central to Pope Benedict XVI’s visit.
articles.abstract: The meeting made clear that a message concerning priestly abuse was central to Pope Benedict XVI’s visit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Pope Benedict XVI came face to face Thursday with a scandal that has left lasting wounds on the American church, holding an unannounced meeting with several victims of sexual abuse by priests in the Boston area.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Sticker Shock in the Organic Aisles
articles.snippet: Rising prices for organic groceries are prompting some consumers to question their devotion to food produced without pesticides, chemical fertilizers or antibiotics.
articles.abstract: Rising prices for organic groceries are prompting some consumers to question their devotion to food produced without pesticides, chemical fertilizers or antibiotics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shoppers have long been willing to pay a premium for organic food. But how much is too much?
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Kim Severson

articles.headline: Workers Get Fewer Hours, Deepening the Downturn
articles.snippet: The shrinking of hours and pay for millions of workers appears to be a bigger contributor to the economic decline than the loss of jobs.
articles.abstract: The shrinking of hours and pay for millions of workers appears to be a bigger contributor to the economic decline than the loss of jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, overtime was a regular feature at the Ludowici Roof Tile factory in eastern Ohio. Not anymore. With orders scarce and crates of unsold tiles piling up across the yard, the company has slowed production and cut working hours, sowing worry and thrift among its workers.

articles.headline: Iceland, a Tiny Dynamo, Loses Steam
articles.snippet: Iceland’s long economic boom has ended in a painful bust, with a collapsing currency, rising inflation, double-digit interest rates and predictions of its first recession since 1992.
articles.abstract: Iceland’s long economic boom has ended in a painful bust, with a collapsing currency, rising inflation, double-digit interest rates and predictions of its first recession since 1992.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Life on this rugged, windswept island has always swung between famine and feast  dependent on the fish in its icy waters and the luck of its fishermen.

articles.headline: Looking Up, but From a Deep Hole
articles.snippet: Since the big banks first realized last fall that their capital situations were perilous, more than $100 billion has been poured into them.
articles.abstract: Since the big banks first realized last fall that their capital situations were perilous, more than $100 billion has been poured into them.

articles.headline: Bottle Maker to Stop Using Plastic Linked to Health Concerns
articles.snippet: Nalgene, the brand that popularized water bottles made from clear and nearly unbreakable polycarbonate, will stop using the plastic because of concern over one of its ingredients.
articles.abstract: Nalgene, the brand that popularized water bottles made from clear and nearly unbreakable polycarbonate, will stop using the plastic because of concern over one of its ingredients.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  Nalgene, the brand that popularized water bottles made from hard, clear and nearly unbreakable polycarbonate, will stop using the plastic because of growing concern over one of its ingredients.

articles.headline: Superdelegates Unswayed by Clinton’s Attacks
articles.snippet: In interviews, 15 superdelegates said that they had not been persuaded much by the attacks on Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: In interviews, 15 superdelegates said that they had not been persuaded much by the attacks on Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout their contentious debate on Wednesday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried again and again to put Senator Barack Obama on the defensive in a pointed attempt, her advisers say, to raise doubts about his electability among a small but powerful audience: the uncommitted superdelegates who will most likely determine the nomination.

articles.headline: Across Globe, Empty Bellies Bring Rising Anger
articles.snippet: Global food prices are spiraling out of reach, sowing discontent and putting pressure on fragile governments.
articles.abstract: Global food prices are spiraling out of reach, sowing discontent and putting pressure on fragile governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Hunger bashed in the front gate of Haiti’s presidential palace. Hunger poured onto the streets, burning tires and taking on soldiers and the police. Hunger sent the country’s prime minister packing.

articles.headline: Google Defies the Economy and Shows Profit Surge
articles.snippet: The Internet search giant on Thursday reported better-than-expected financial results for the first three months of the year, igniting a huge rally in the company shares.
articles.abstract: The Internet search giant on Thursday reported better-than-expected financial results for the first three months of the year, igniting a huge rally in the company shares.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The American economy may be weakening, but Google said once again that the slowdown has not affected its business.
